trans-unit.source: Use Hadoop Pig with SSH on an HDInsight cluster | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Hadoop Pig with SSH on an HDInsight cluster | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how connect to a Linux-based Hadoop cluster with SSH, and then use the Pig command to run Pig Latin statements interactively, or as a batch job.
trans-unit.target: Learn how connect to a Linux-based Hadoop cluster with SSH, and then use the Pig command to run Pig Latin statements interactively, or as a batch job.

trans-unit.source: Run Pig jobs on a Linux-based cluster with the Pig command (SSH)
trans-unit.target: Run Pig jobs on a Linux-based cluster with the Pig command (SSH)

trans-unit.source: In this document you will walk through the process of connecting to a Linux-based Azure HDInsight cluster by using Secure Shell (SSH), then using the Pig command to run Pig Latin statements interactively, or as a batch job.
trans-unit.target: In this document you will walk through the process of connecting to a Linux-based Azure HDInsight cluster by using Secure Shell (SSH), then using the Pig command to run Pig Latin statements interactively, or as a batch job.

trans-unit.source: The Pig Latin programming language allows you to describe transformations that are applied to the input data to produce the desired output.
trans-unit.target: The Pig Latin programming language allows you to describe transformations that are applied to the input data to produce the desired output.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you are already familiar with using Linux-based Hadoop servers, but are new to HDInsight, see [Linux-based HDInsight Tips](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-information.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you are already familiar with using Linux-based Hadoop servers, but are new to HDInsight, see [Linux-based HDInsight Tips](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-information.md).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete the steps in this article, you will need the following.
trans-unit.target: To complete the steps in this article, you will need the following.

trans-unit.source: A Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop on HDInsight) cluster.
trans-unit.target: A Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop on HDInsight) cluster.

trans-unit.source: An SSH client.
trans-unit.target: An SSH client.

trans-unit.source: Linux, Unix, and Mac OS should come with an SSH client.
trans-unit.target: Linux, Unix, and Mac OS should come with an SSH client.

trans-unit.source: Windows users must download a client, such as [PuTTY](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).
trans-unit.target: Windows users must download a client, such as [PuTTY](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).

trans-unit.source: Connect with SSH
trans-unit.target: Connect with SSH

trans-unit.source: Connect to the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your HDInsight cluster by using the SSH command.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your HDInsight cluster by using the SSH command.

trans-unit.source: The FQDN will be the name you gave the cluster, then **.azurehdinsight.net**.
trans-unit.target: The FQDN will be the name you gave the cluster, then **.azurehdinsight.net**.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following would connect to a cluster named **myhdinsight**.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following would connect to a cluster named **myhdinsight**.

trans-unit.source: **If you provided a certificate key for SSH authentication** when you created the HDInsight cluster, you may need to specify the location of the private key on your client system.
trans-unit.target: **If you provided a certificate key for SSH authentication** when you created the HDInsight cluster, you may need to specify the location of the private key on your client system.

trans-unit.source: **If you provided a password for SSH authentication** when you created the HDInsight cluster, you will need to provide the password when prompted.
trans-unit.target: **If you provided a password for SSH authentication** when you created the HDInsight cluster, you will need to provide the password when prompted.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using SSH with HDInsight, see [Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, OS X, and Unix](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-use-ssh-unix.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on using SSH with HDInsight, see [Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, OS X, and Unix](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-use-ssh-unix.md).

trans-unit.source: PuTTY (Windows-based clients)
trans-unit.target: PuTTY (Windows-based clients)

trans-unit.source: Windows does not provide a built-in SSH client.
trans-unit.target: Windows does not provide a built-in SSH client.

trans-unit.source: We recommend using **PuTTY**, which can be downloaded from [http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).
trans-unit.target: We recommend using **PuTTY**, which can be downloaded from [http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).

trans-unit.source: For more information on using PuTTY, see [Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows ](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-use-ssh-windows.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on using PuTTY, see [Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows ](hdinsight-hadoop-linux-use-ssh-windows.md).

trans-unit.source: Use the Pig command
trans-unit.target: Use the Pig command

trans-unit.source: Once connected, start the Pig command-line interface (CLI) by using the following command.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, start the Pig command-line interface (CLI) by using the following command.

trans-unit.source: After a moment, you should see a `grunt>` prompt.
trans-unit.target: After a moment, you should see a `grunt>` prompt.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following statement.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following statement.

trans-unit.source: This command loads the contents of the sample.log file into LOGS.
trans-unit.target: This command loads the contents of the sample.log file into LOGS.

trans-unit.source: You can view the contents of the file by using the following.
trans-unit.target: You can view the contents of the file by using the following.

trans-unit.source: Next, transform the data by applying a regular expression to extract only the logging level from each record by using the following.
trans-unit.target: Next, transform the data by applying a regular expression to extract only the logging level from each record by using the following.

trans-unit.source: You can use **DUMP** to view the data after the transformation.
trans-unit.target: You can use **DUMP** to view the data after the transformation.

trans-unit.source: In this case, use `DUMP LEVELS;`.
trans-unit.target: In this case, use `DUMP LEVELS;`.

trans-unit.source: Continue applying transformations by using the following statements.
trans-unit.target: Continue applying transformations by using the following statements.

trans-unit.source: Use `DUMP` to view the result of the transformation after each step.
trans-unit.target: Use `DUMP` to view the result of the transformation after each step.

trans-unit.source:
StatementWhat it does
FILTEREDLEVELS = FILTER LEVELS by LOGLEVEL is not null;Removes rows that contain a null value for the log level and stores the results into FILTEREDLEVELS.
GROUPEDLEVELS = GROUP FILTEREDLEVELS by LOGLEVEL;Groups the rows by log level and stores the results into GROUPEDLEVELS.
FREQUENCIES = foreach GROUPEDLEVELS generate group as LOGLEVEL, COUNT(FILTEREDLEVELS.LOGLEVEL) as COUNT;Creates a new set of data that contains each unique log level value and how many times it occurs.
trans-unit.target:
StatementWhat it does
FILTEREDLEVELS = FILTER LEVELS by LOGLEVEL is not null;Removes rows that contain a null value for the log level and stores the results into FILTEREDLEVELS.
GROUPEDLEVELS = GROUP FILTEREDLEVELS by LOGLEVEL;Groups the rows by log level and stores the results into GROUPEDLEVELS.
FREQUENCIES = foreach GROUPEDLEVELS generate group as LOGLEVEL, COUNT(FILTEREDLEVELS.LOGLEVEL) as COUNT;Creates a new set of data that contains each unique log level value and how many times it occurs.

trans-unit.source: This is stored into FREQUENCIES. RESULT = order FREQUENCIES by COUNT desc;Orders the log levels by count (descending) and stores into RESULT.
trans-unit.target: This is stored into FREQUENCIES. RESULT = order FREQUENCIES by COUNT desc;Orders the log levels by count (descending) and stores into RESULT.

trans-unit.source: You can also save the results of a transformation by using the `STORE` statement.
trans-unit.target: You can also save the results of a transformation by using the `STORE` statement.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following saves the `RESULT` to the **/example/data/pigout** directory on the default storage container for your cluster.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following saves the `RESULT` to the **/example/data/pigout** directory on the default storage container for your cluster.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The data is stored in the specified directory in files named **part-nnnnn**.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The data is stored in the specified directory in files named **part-nnnnn**.

trans-unit.source: If the directory already exists, you will receive an error.
trans-unit.target: If the directory already exists, you will receive an error.

trans-unit.source: To exit the grunt prompt, enter the following statement.
trans-unit.target: To exit the grunt prompt, enter the following statement.

trans-unit.source: Pig Latin batch files
trans-unit.target: Pig Latin batch files

trans-unit.source: You can also use the Pig command to run Pig Latin contained in a file.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the Pig command to run Pig Latin contained in a file.

trans-unit.source: After exiting the grunt prompt, use the following command to pipe STDIN into a file named **pigbatch.pig**.
trans-unit.target: After exiting the grunt prompt, use the following command to pipe STDIN into a file named **pigbatch.pig**.

trans-unit.source: This file will be created in the home directory for the account you are logged in to for the SSH session.
trans-unit.target: This file will be created in the home directory for the account you are logged in to for the SSH session.

trans-unit.source: Type or paste the following lines, and then use Ctrl+D when finished.
trans-unit.target: Type or paste the following lines, and then use Ctrl+D when finished.

trans-unit.source: Use the following to run the **pigbatch.pig** file by using the Pig command.
trans-unit.target: Use the following to run the **pigbatch.pig** file by using the Pig command.

trans-unit.source: Once the batch job finishes, you should see the following output, which should be the same as when you used `DUMP RESULT;` in the previous steps.
trans-unit.target: Once the batch job finishes, you should see the following output, which should be the same as when you used `DUMP RESULT;` in the previous steps.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: As you can see, the Pig command allows you to interactively run MapReduce operations by using Pig Latin, as well as run statements stored in a batch file.
trans-unit.target: As you can see, the Pig command allows you to interactively run MapReduce operations by using Pig Latin, as well as run statements stored in a batch file.

trans-unit.target: Next steps
